p.seg: STATE OF NEBRASKA Biennial Report OF THE Superintendent OF THE State Reformatory for Men LINCOLN. NEBRASKA To the Governor and the Board of Control of State Institutions / For the Period Ending June 30, 1923

FOREWORD Tgjlis Excellency, the Governor : The Board of Control herewith transmits the Fifth Biennial Report of the State Institutions of Nebraska for the period ending June 30, 1923. The biennium formerly ended on November 30 of each even-numbered year, but this date was changed by an act of the legislature, so that this report really covers a period of thirty-one months from December 1, 1920, to June 30, 1923. During the period, no change has occurred in the personnel of the Board, but several changes have been made in the chief officers of institutions. Dr. Beverly A. Finkle, superintendent of the Orthopedic Hospital, Lincoln, Nebraska, resigned to enter private practice, and was succeeded on August 23, 1921, by Dr. J. H. Matthai. Miss Amy V. Stevens, who had been superintendent of the Home for Dependent Children, Lincoln, Nebraska, for a number of years, resigned on July 5, 1922, being succeeded by her sister, Miss Nellie Stevens. The latter served until February 19, 1923, when her resignation was received, and Miss Lena Driever was appointed to the position. We call attention with pride and pleasure to the fact that the report shows the institutions to have gone through the bien - nium without incurring any deficiencies ; although the cost of living, and consequently the cost of supporting the state's depen - dents, has certainly not decreased since the appropriations were made for the biennium. Some improvements of a permament character have been made at the various institutions during the period covered by this report. A hospital building, bakery and scullery have been erected at the Nebraska Institution for Feeble Minded, Beatrice, Nebraska ; a cottage for girls at the Girls' Training School, Geneva, Nebraska ; a hospital building at the Soldiers and Sailors' Home, Burkett,

4 Nebraska ; a gymnasium building at the State Industrial School, Kearney, Nebraska ; a hospital building at the Hospital for Tuberculous, Kearney, Nebraska ; a farm house and a barn at the Lincoln State Hospital, Lincoln, Nebraska ; a warehouse at the State Penitentiary, Lincoln, Nebraska ; a hospital building at the Soldiers and Sailors' Home, Milford, Nebraska; a kitchen building at the Norfolk State Hospital, Norfolk, Nebraska ; a main building at the State Reformatory for Women, York, Nebraska. These buildings were badly needed, and they will have to be followed by others in the very near future if our wards are to be properly, efficiently and economically cared for. The legislature just past made provision for two or three buildings, but failed to see the necessity for several others that were urgently requested. Brief mention was made in the last report of the establishment of the Reformatory for Men at Lincoln, but the importance of the institution calls, we believe, for rather more extended notice. This institution was established as a result, primarily, of a wide recognition of the need of segregating young first-term offenders from more mature criminals. The legislature of 1921 authorized the establishment, therefore, of such an institution, making an initial approproation of $300,000. Of this sum the Board ex - pended $37,500 for 10 acres and a brick building known as the Hayward Military Academy, later buying about 152 acres of contiguous land for the sum of $49,531.25. This land is used for farming, stock raising, dairying, and intensive gardening. Various trades are taught such as tailoring, shoe repairing, carpentry and joinery, brick laying, electricity, automobile repairing, launder - ing, engineering, firing, and barbering. The manual labor about the institution is, of course, performed by the inmates, of which there are at this date 189. Mr. A. W. Miller, the superintendent, is doing much constructive work with the young men committed to his charge, and we believe the institution is amply justifying itself. The difficulty of employing the penitentiary inmates at suitable labor that does not conflict too much with the prerogatives of the free workers of our state, has been pretty well overcome. The state still operates the fibre furniture factory which has been at the prison for some years, and has also established relations with the Oberman Company by which shirts are made and disposed of with a minimum of competition with free labor.

7 Home for Dependent Children, Lincoln — Grand Total 4,538,783.65 At its various institutions the state owns something over 4000 acres of land, of which in excess of 3500 are in farm and garden. About 800 acres are rented in addition. Details of operation are given in the reports from the several superintendents which are appended hereto. The health of the inmate population has been generally good during the past biennium. We are pleased to be able to report that no epidemic has broken out at any of the institutions, and our medical men have been able to cope with such sporadic cases of contagious disease as have appeared. In conclusion we wish to express our appreciation of the efforts of the officers and employees of the various institutions in striving to bring about a betterment of the living conditions of the wards under their care. We wish also to thank the Governor for his manifestations of interest and for his assistance in the work of this department, and we trust that he will continue his efforts to help us provide better means of caring for the wards of the state. 19 To the Governor and the Board of Control of State Institutions, Lincoln. Nebraska. I herewith submit the first report of this institution, covering the period beginning October 1, 1921, and ending June 30, 1923. On the date first named, the institution was opened with a population of eighty persons , seventy-seven of whom were transferred from the penitentiary. Many discomforts were experienced during the winter of 1921 in housing the inmates and officers from the fact that the building and remodeling had to virtually be carried on over our heads. But despite these in - conveniences and discomforts, the construction has gone steadily forward until we now have at the close of the bicnnium, a structure complete in detail of plumbing, heating and lighting. During the year that has elapsed since the first occupation, the following work in construction has been completed : A substantial brick boiler house and engine room have been built to meet the needs of the institution, and will suffice for some years to come; a concrete smoke-stack one hundred and five feet high ; a steel water-tower and reservoir, with a capacity of fifty thousand gallons ; an emergency reservoir with a capacity of nearly sixty thousand gallons ; a new well and pump-house with a substantial guardhouse above ; a three hundred foot tunnel connect - ing the main building with the heating plant ; a woven steel wire fence enclosing the seven acres — this fence is emplanted in a base of concrete. Outside the fence we have erected a good hog-house from lumber salvaged from old buildings ; a brick garage with a capacity for eight cars which was built entirely by the inmates ; a large vegetable cellar of concrete with a capacity for a carload of potatoes, cabbage and other vegetables; a storehouse for lumber, building material and tools ; a septic tank ; a transformer house ; six manholes.

20 There are occasions in all institutional work when stricter discipline must obtain for such as refuse to abide by the rules; and for these cases there has been erected within the enclosure, a concrete structure or so-called jail, where the more serious offenders may be punished by complete isolation. We are happy to state that while this building has not been brought into requi - sition to any appreciable extent; it nevertheless has added to the morale of the place. All material entering into new construction and remodeling, which material consisted of tons of cement, sand, lime, brick and stone, had to be hauled to the institution over roads that at times were almost impassible. Our school system was inaugurated in October, 1922, and is a wonderful asset to our institution, one in which the general public and all welfare workers should take a hearty interest. Instruction is given in all the grades up to the eighth ; and the school is in operation six hours a day for five days of the week. To get as far away as possible from the stigma of prison life and the handicap incurring from prison servitude the reformatory was established ; and in this school work we seek to give the greatest possible aid in the up-building of character and to restore to citizenship a finished product, an upright human being. In addition to our school, we have established several useful activities : A manual training school, where many useful articles of furniture are made and furniture for the insitution is made and repaired ; a tailor shop in which much of the clothing worn by the inmates is made, and where worn garments are repaired ; a shoe shop which is busy all the time repairing inmates' shoes and the shoes for other state institutions ; an automobile repair shop where our truck and automobiles are kept in repair; a barber shop where a number of inmates are learning a trade, and where a number who have served their time have learned a useful trade that enables them to support their families ; a modern and well - equipped steam laundry that gives employment to inmates who are thus learning a useful trade ; an ice plant that furnishes ice for the institution, and gives perfect refrigeration for our perishable supplies; paint, plumbing, and electrical shops complete the list of activities; and each department is under the supervision of a competent and skilled foreman.

21 We also have a music department, in which the inmates are receiving instruction. This department is a valued adjunct to our institution in consequence of which there is always a big waiting list of those who desire instruction in orchestra and band music. It is the constant aim and effort of the officers, both by precept and example, to influence the inmates to lead upright and honest lives. Their spiritual welfare is subserved by chapel exercises which are held each Sunday and consist of song services, lectures and sermons by ministers residing in Lincoln and neighboring towns. The religious beliefs of our inmates are respected and all denominations are alike invited to minister to our spiritual needs. The legislature of 1923 appropriated fifty thousand dollars for the erection of suitable buildings in so far as the sum would suffice and fifteen thousand dollars for a building for industrial activities. Plans are being worked out for both buildings. Respectfully submitted, A. W. MILLER, Superintendent.
